qas.question: Why were problems created when transferring files between systems?

answers.text: The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage

qas.question: Teletype machines had to have two codes to termanate a line, what were they?

answers.text: "Carriage Return" (which moves the printhead to the beginning of the line) and "Line Feed" (which advances the paper one line without moving the printhead)

qas.question: Where does the name "Carriage Return" come from?

answers.text: on a manual typewriter the carriage holding the paper moved while the position where the typebars struck the ribbon remained stationary

qas.question: What side does the carriage have to be pushed to when starting a new line?

plausible_answers.text: The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage

qas.question: Why were problems created when beginning a line?

plausible_answers.text: "Carriage Return" (which moves the printhead to the beginning of the line) and "Line Feed" (which advances the paper one line without moving the printhead)

qas.question: Teletype machines had to have entire carriages to terminate a line, what were they?
What side does the carriage have to be pushed to without moving the printhead?
What moves the printhead to the various operating systems?
Which advances the paper where the typebars strike the ribbon?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>The inherent ambiguity of many control characters, combined with their historical usage<b4_0/><a0_0/>, created problems when transferring "plain text" files between systems. The best example of this is the newline problem on various operating systems. Teletype machines required that a line of text be terminated with both <a1_0><b5_0>"<b7_0>Carriage Return<b7_0/>" (which moves the printhead to the beginning of the line) and "<b8_0>Line Feed<b8_0/>" (which advances the paper one line without moving the printhead)<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The name "Carriage Return" comes from the fact that <a2_0>on a manual typewriter the carriage holding the paper moved while the position where the typebars struck the ribbon remained stationary<a2_0/>. The entire carriage had to be pushed (returned) to the <a3_0><b6_0>right<b6_0/><a3_0/> in order to position the left margin of the paper for the next line.
